prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: Confidential business information includes trade secrets, formulae, client lists and internal office memoranda, among others.[1] All that is required is that the creator of the information “used his brain and thus produced a result which can only be produced by somebody who goes through the same process”.[2] There is no requirement that the product be novel or non-obvious in the sense of patent law.

One of the most important distinctions between trade secrets and confidential business information is that an employee cannot use or disclose any confidential information or trade secrets while he or she is employed. However, once the employee has quit the place of employment, he or she is only prohibited from using the former employer's trade secrets (chemical formulae, secret processes and customer, supplier and employee lists), but not from using other types of confidential business information such as technical expertise and knowledge acquired during the course of employment. However, where the technical expertise and know-how would enable the former employee to profit from his or her wrong, some courts have held that the former employee will be prevented from using that information.[3]

Unlike trade secrets, confidential information need not involve an ongoing process. However, it has been argued that the information must be of the type that justifies protection on public policy grounds.[4]

Confidentiality may be judged both objectively and subjectively—objectively to determine whether the information is readily available to those who might wish to use it, and subjectively to see if the holder believes it to be non-public and expresses an intention to ensure that it remains confidential.[5]

The rights and obligations of those owning or using confidential information are not specifically dealt with in any one piece of legislation. Some aspects of confidential information are, however, dealt with in the Criminal Code[6] and in the Privacy Acts of certain provinces. The Supreme Court of Canada has specifically provided that, in order for the federal Parliament to be able to enact legislation specifically dealing with trade secrets and confidential information, there would have to be a connection with trade and commerce and a central regulatory body. Thus, the federal Parliament has no power to enact legislation except in so far as the exploitation of confidential information is considered a criminal act.[7] Today an inventor must choose between patent, copyright and trade secret or confidential information protection to safeguard his or her rights. On the one hand, a truly “protectable” secret such as a chemical formula requires no legal protection. At the other extreme, if “reverse engineering” is simple enough that a skilled observer looking at the product could unravel the secret, then the confidential information cannot be protected even with legal assistance. However, there is within these extremes a spectrum of inventive activities for which legal protection of trade secrets and confidential information is to some degree effective.
